channel.title: botar's old time radio
channel.itunes:author: www.botar.us
channel.description: we deliver the best of old time radio shows to your door fresh daily. shows like the shadow, fibber mcgee and molly, boston blackie, the green hornet, X-minus one plus so much more.
channel.itunes:subtitle: OTR by botar
channel.itunes:summary: old time radio shows from the 30s 40s and 50s delivered fresh to your door daily.

item.title: the whistler, search for maxine 03/13/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A man trying to borrow 5000 dollars from his drunken cousin accidentally kills him. He then discovers that the murder was overheard on the telephone.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/13/1949
item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, writer at work, 10/12/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A fascinating look behind the scenes at a writer of radio scripts.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/12/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: challenge of the yukon, caught by a button 08/21/1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Sergeant Preston finds the body of Duke Wells and follows the footprints in the snow to The Idle Hours Cafe where he drinks milk. Preston suspects Bart Smith and uses a ruse to prove his theory.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/21/1943
item.itunes:summary: Challenge of the Yukon was a radio series that began on Detroits station WXYZ. The series was first heard on February 3, 1938. The program was an adventure series about Sergeant William Preston of the NorthWest Mounted Police and his lead alaskan husky sled dog, Yukon King, as they fought evildoers in the Northern wilderness during the Gold Rush of the 1890s.
item.itunes:keywords: challenge of the yukon,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: jungle jim, episode 142. prepatations for leaving camp 07/16/1938
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 142
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/16/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 175, leroys new teacher 09/09/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Leroy is doing so well in school that Gildersleeve buys him a set of encyclopedias.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/09/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, waring summe replacement 06/08/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: fibber mcgee and molly
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/08/1948
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: the saint, its snow use 10/29/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of the saint
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/29/1950
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. Later in 1945, Brian Aherne took over the role when the show switched over to CBS. Then in 1947, probably the most famous Radio Saint of all time, Vincent Price, added his golden voice to the role. Vincent Price was once quoted as saying the most difficult thing about the show was coming up with new and unique ways to get conked on the head. After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1010 horatio F horn detective p10 07/15/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/15/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: burns and allen, georges birthday 09/19/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Today is a very special day in the Burns home as it is Georges birthday. But George is far from festive as only Gracie remembered the great occasion and he is pretty upset by it.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/19/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: escape, time machine 10/27/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The classic story about two adventurers in the year 100,080 in the land of the Morlocks and the Eloi. The program was broadcast on the west coast on October 27, 1950.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/27/1950
item.itunes:summary: Escape was radios leading anthology series of high adventure, airing on CBS from July 7, 1947 to September 25, 1954. Broadcasting a wide range of stories including science fiction, horror, and murder mysteries.

item.title: tales of the texas rangers, troop train 04/06/1952
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A soldier deserts from the Army, kills his fellow deserter, and finds himself accused of beating up an old rancher.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/06/1952
item.itunes:summary: Joel McCrea stars as Texas Ranger Jace Pearson in this thirty minute western adventure series. The shows are all reenactments of incidents from Texas Ranger history. The Texas lawman and his trusty steed, Charcoal, would track a criminal, often a killer, throughout the vast 260,000 square miles of Texas.
item.itunes:keywords: tales of the texas ranger,joel mccrea,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, robber bridegroom 05/14/1955
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Franklin Reeves fiancee is kidnapped off a stagecoach. The robber returns and surrenders for a strange reason.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/14/1955
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. Later in 1945, Brian Aherne took over the role when the show switched over to CBS. Then in 1947, probably the most famous Radio Saint of all time, Vincent Price, added his golden voice to the role. Vincent Price was once quoted as saying the most difficult thing about the show was coming up with new and unique ways to get conked on the head. After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1006 horatio F horn detective p6 07/09/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/09/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/30/1955
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.description: A very well written, clever allegory about the first astronauts to land on Venus and the talking vegetables that live there.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/14/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/18/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.title: the saint, death of the saint 07/16/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A blond woman knocking frantically on his door disturbs Simon Templar. She has been followed and fears for her life. But it appears it is all an elaborate act to lead him to the man who is going to kill him.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/16/1950
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. Later in 1945, Brian Aherne took over the role when the show switched over to CBS. Then in 1947, probably the most famous Radio Saint of all time, Vincent Price, added his golden voice to the role. Vincent Price was once quoted as saying the most difficult thing about the show was coming up with new and unique ways to get conked on the head. After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1000 clan of the fiery cross p16 07/01/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/01/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: the saint, prize fighter 06/11/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Simon Templar meets a woman called Peggy on the bus and she asks his help for her boyfriend Breckon Ridge who is the manager of prizefighter Benny the Battler a lousy middleweight fighter who has no chance of winning the fight scheduled for that night.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/11/1950
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. Later in 1945, Brian Aherne took over the role when the show switched over to CBS. Then in 1947, probably the most famous Radio Saint of all time, Vincent Price, added his golden voice to the role. Vincent Price was once quoted as saying the most difficult thing about the show was coming up with new and unique ways to get conked on the head. After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/18/1950
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. item.title: adventures of superman, ep996 clan of the fiery cross p12 06/25/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/25/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: burns and allen, jose itubi and deems taylor 03/09/1944
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gracie is still determined to play at Paul Whitemans concert at Carnegie Hall next Tuesday. She is practicing now and George and Paul are trying to make her listen to reason. Even a visit from famous concert pianist Jose Iturbi will not convince her that she is anything but a brilliant pianist.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/09/1944
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.itunes:keywords: tales of the texas ranger,joel mccrea,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, horse deal 03/26/1955
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Charlie Deeshas horses have been stolen, and the thief is selling them all over Dodge.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/26/1955
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, only johnny knows, 08/10/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A look at child rearing in America since Colonial times.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/10/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 134. all hands on deck 05/21/1938
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 134
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/21/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 167, marjories boy troubles 05/06/1945

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/06/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, overnight trip 03/30/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Fibber and Molly spend the night at the Wistful Vista Plaza.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/30/1948
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: the saint, old mans car 05/26/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The Saint is walking the streets when he hears a heated argument between three men, they are trying to steal an old mans car from under him. The Saint rushes over to assist the old man, and the criminals leave the scene.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/26/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. Later in 1945, Brian Aherne took over the role when the show switched over to CBS. Then in 1947, probably the most famous Radio Saint of all time, Vincent Price, added his golden voice to the role. Vincent Price was once quoted as saying the most difficult thing about the show was coming up with new and unique ways to get conked on the head. After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.title: the saint, color blind killer 09/18/1949

item.description: The Saint meets up with Barbara, a famous movie actress. Something has scared her, but she will not say what. item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/18/1949
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. item.title: adventures of superman, ep990 clan of the fiery cross p6 06/17/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/17/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/07/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.title: the saint, gangster district attorney 10/15/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The Saint refuses to be forced out of town even when offered 5000 dollars to do so. He wants to get the guy who killed John Daniels a friend of his.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/15/1947
item.itunes:summary:
The Saint 1940 - 1951
Was first brought to life on the radio in 1940 on Radio Athlone. It was then a five year wait before NBC picked up the option, and featured Edgar Barrier as Simon Templar, alias The Saint. Later in 1945, Brian Aherne took over the role when the show switched over to CBS. Then in 1947, probably the most famous Radio Saint of all time, Vincent Price, added his golden voice to the role. Vincent Price was once quoted as saying the most difficult thing about the show was coming up with new and unique ways to get conked on the head. After a large number of episodes, Price finally left and his replacement Barry Sullivan only lasted a few episodes before the show was cancelled. It was resurrected due to public demand, with Vincent Price returning to save the day.

item.title: burns and allen, expecting a baby 11/10/1942
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: George wants a shirt washing out but Gracie is expecting her friends from the Beverley Hills Uplift Society.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/10/1942
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/30/1950
item.itunes:summary: Escape was radios leading anthology series of high adventure, airing on CBS from July 7, 1947 to September 25, 1954. Broadcasting a wide range of stories including science fiction, horror, and murder mysteries.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep986 clan of the fiery cross p2 06/11/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/11/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/07/1951

The Texas lawman and his trusty steed, Charcoal, would track a criminal, often a killer, throughout the vast 260,000 square miles of Texas.

item.title: gunsmoke, poor pearl 02/19/1955
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Willy Calhoun had come to Dodge to claim his bride Pearl with a rifle.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/19/1955
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, portrait of paris, 07/06/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: David Schoenbruns sound portrait of the city, the show truly captures a Parisian flavor through fine radio journalism.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/06/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 129. lil hears jim has disappeared 04/16/1938
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 129
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/16/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 162, old flame violet 03/25/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/25/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, truth on washingtons birthday 02/22/1949

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/22/1949
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: boston blackie, pudgy and the stolen tire racket 06/01/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: While trying to chase a tire thief named Pudgy, Blackie has an accident and winds up in the hospital.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/01/1949
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/16/1943
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep980 al vincents corrupt political machine p10 06/03/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/03/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/15/1955
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 124. in search of the treasure 03/12/1938

item.description: jungle jim, episode 124
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/12/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/04/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/30/1951
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.title: boston blackie, fifty thousand dollars in bonds 02/09/1949

item.description: A man disappears from the roof of a building and turns up dead in a ditch, miles away.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/09/1949
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.title: burns and allen, professor thorndyke 10/21/1940
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The Famous psychiatrist Professor Alvin W. Thorndyke has had Gracie under observation all week. In fact he is been living at the Allen home trying to find out how a mind of her type functions. According to the theory of psychiatry one can tell the inner workings of a mind by watching the persons reactions but Gracie rarely says a sane word.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/21/1940
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep970 hate mongers organization p25 05/20/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/20/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep966 hate mongers organization p21 05/14/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/14/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A seeing eye dog leads Jace Pearson to an interesting story of murder and a 40,000 dollar treasure in the desert wilderness. Based on events of March 6, 1940.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/11/1951
item.itunes:summary: Joel McCrea stars as Texas Ranger Jace Pearson in this thirty minute western adventure series. The shows are all reenactments of incidents from Texas Ranger history. The Texas lawman and his trusty steed, Charcoal, would track a criminal, often a killer, throughout the vast 260,000 square miles of Texas.
item.itunes:keywords: tales of the texas ranger,joel mccrea,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, bone hunters 12/11/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: It appears as if Noley Meeker has murdered Bill Zant. The two buffalo bone hunters had been trying to kill each other in Dodge.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/11/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: the whistler, bird of prey 03/31/1948

item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, record collectors, 04/27/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: John Dehner interviews two record collectors who play some items from their collections.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/27/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 119. jim has another plan 02/05/1938
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 119
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/05/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 148, dodging a process server 12/17/1944
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gildy goes to great lengths to avoid the suit he is sure Miss Del Rey is starting against him.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/17/1944
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, white christmas tree 12/18/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Fibber paints his Christmas tree white.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/18/1945
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: boston blackie, killer lightning 12/08/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A scheming couple commit the perfect murder by using lightning to kill.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/08/1948
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.title: burns and allen, kansas city 06/06/1944
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: It is morning in Burnss home and while Gracie sips her after breakfast coffee George stares gloomily in to space. On his plate are a couple of untouched cold fried eggs, which look much happier than he does.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/06/1944
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/18/1948
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.title: burns and allen, thanksgiving show 11/18/1940
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gracie could not make it to the show on account of her Grandaddy being sick and it is not that George needs Gracie to do the show but he decides if she can not come in he will to go to her house. George tells Gracie that tonights show is about Thanksgiving and then has to explain to her what it is.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/18/1940
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep960 hate mongers organization p15 05/06/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/06/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, how to kill a woman 11/20/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The stage has been robbed and a passenger murdered in cold blood. Suspicion falls on Nate Pilcher, a friend of Jesse Daggett.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/20/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, speaking of cinderella, 04/06/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A well done, fun look at the old story told the conventional way, and then a modern Madison Avenue style version.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/06/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 116. disposing of the guards 01/15/1938

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/15/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.

item.description: jungle jim, episode 114
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/01/1938
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, picnic in the orchard 05/16/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/16/1950
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. item.title: boston blackie, professor beasley case 06/30/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Professor Beasley is murdered when Blackie and Mary return to their old alma mater.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/30/1948
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/11/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: boston blackie, william larson extortion case 03/17/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: When William Larson refuses to pay further blackmail, he is found shot twice in the head. Larsons niece and nephew hated him, and so did the housekeeper.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/17/1948
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/23/1940
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep948 hate mongers organization p3 04/18/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/18/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/10/1950
item.itunes:summary: Joel McCrea stars as Texas Ranger Jace Pearson in this thirty minute western adventure series. The shows are all reenactments of incidents from Texas Ranger history. The Texas lawman and his trusty steed, Charcoal, would track a criminal, often a killer, throughout the vast 260,000 square miles of Texas.
item.itunes:keywords: tales of the texas ranger,joel mccrea,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, kitty caught 10/16/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The Karp Brothers rob the bank in Dodge and take Kitty with them as a hostage.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/16/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: the whistler, man of distinction 10/15/1947

item.title: cbs radio workshop, voice of new york, 03/02/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: New York is a city of sound and that sound is the voice of the city, the voice of New York. Tony Swartz with his portable tape recorder has recorded the voice of New York and leads you through a unique venture in to the dramatic form and poetic mood to the actual sounds of New York City.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/02/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 111. trapped in the old monks cell 12/11/1937
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 111
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/11/1937
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, new fire truck 04/19/1949

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/19/1949
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.title: gunsmoke, matt gets it 10/02/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Dan Grat comes to Dodge on the lam from Amarillo. After shooting the sheriff of Amarillo, he faces Marshal Dillon in a gunfight.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/02/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, season of disbelief, 02/17/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Season And Disbelief and Hail And Farewell are two unusual and provocative character studies by Ray Bradbury. For CBS Ray Bradbury also narrates these stories.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/17/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/27/1937
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, mollys toothache 05/25/1948

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: boston blackie, invention worth a killing 01/14/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: boston blackie
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/14/1948
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.
