item.title: burns and allen, george owes money 09/09/1940
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: George has won the 200,000 dollar case against Elsie Trellafas and today is the last day to pay the 25 dollar court fees. Gracie tells him not to pay it as she knows someone who can get them off with it. However trying to track him down costs thousands of dollars in phone calls.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/09/1940
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep942 story of the century p8 04/10/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/10/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/04/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/13/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: cbs radio workshop, brave new world p1, 01/27/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The first show of the series. The classic story of the future, narrated by the author. Aldous Huxley.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/27/1956
item.itunes:summary: The CBS Radio Workshop was an experimental dramatic radio anthology series that aired on CBS from January 27, 1956, until September 22, 1957. It was a revival of the earlier Columbia Workshop, broadcast by CBS from 1936 to 1943, and it used some of the same writers and directors employed on the earlier series. The CBS Radio Workshop was one of American network radios last attempts to hold onto, and perhaps recapture, some of the demographics they had lost to television in the post World War Two era.

Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.title: boston blackie, poetry in my soul 07/30/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: boston blackie
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/30/1947
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/18/1944
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: boston blackie, johnny burns woolens 07/02/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Johnny Cash Burns sells imported woolens, and he is allbusiness. He also uses a helicopter and post hypnotic suggestions.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/02/1947
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, young mans fancy 08/18/1951
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A hot day, and a visit to a Yugoslav American friend who runs a fruit stand, leads Marlowe to a confrontation with a young man with a problem.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/18/1951
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: burns and allen, george disguises 10/07/1940
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Hughie Sallis the gangster has been threatening to kill George. To avoid been recognised George dresses in Gracies clothes and pretended he was her aunt Clara.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/07/1940
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep928 mystery of the dragons teeth p4 03/20/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/20/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/29/1950
item.itunes:summary: Joel McCrea stars as Texas Ranger Jace Pearson in this thirty minute western adventure series. The shows are all reenactments of incidents from Texas Ranger history. The Texas lawman and his trusty steed, Charcoal, would track a criminal, often a killer, throughout the vast 260,000 square miles of Texas.
item.itunes:keywords: tales of the texas ranger,joel mccrea,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, joe phy 08/09/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Marshal Joe Phy is running the town of Elkader with an iron fist, until Matt Dillon comes to town.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/09/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: nbc university theatre, trents last case 07/29/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/29/1950
item.itunes:summary: In 1944, NBC brought the worlds greatest novels to radio, offering high quality adaptations of some of the great works of literature. In 1948, the series was retitled NBC University theatre of the air and production was moved to Hollywood. The first broadcast of the new series aired July 30, 1948. In 1948, the Peabody was awarded to the NBC University Theatre.

item.description: jungle jim, episode 101
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/02/1937
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/14/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/10/1952
item.itunes:summary: Joel McCrea stars as Texas Ranger Jace Pearson in this thirty minute western adventure series. The shows are all reenactments of incidents from Texas Ranger history. The Texas lawman and his trusty steed, Charcoal, would track a criminal, often a killer, throughout the vast 260,000 square miles of Texas.

item.title: gunsmoke, mott for murder 07/26/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Red Samples accuses Marshal Dillon of murdering his partner. Wild Bill Kickok is sent to arrest Dillon so he can stand trial.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/26/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/02/1950
item.itunes:summary: In 1944, NBC brought the worlds greatest novels to radio, offering high quality adaptations of some of the great works of literature. In 1948, the series was retitled NBC University theatre of the air and production was moved to Hollywood. The first broadcast of the new series aired July 30, 1948. In 1948, the Peabody was awarded to the NBC University Theatre.

item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, fixing the back step 03/04/1952
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Fibber has finally decided to fix the back step, which is not as easy as it sounds.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/04/1952
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 128, gildy compaign HQ 05/28/1944
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gildersleeves campaign for the office of mayor continues.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/28/1944
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: boston blackie, peters mix up 02/04/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Walter Peters body is found in a lake, with Bostons Blackies name on his corpse.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/04/1947
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, life can be murder 07/21/1951

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/21/1951
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: burns and allen, elsie trellfas is suing george 08/26/1940
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Alice tells George that Elsie Trellasfas is taking him to court for 10,000 dollars. When Alice tells her that it will cost her 10,000 dollars in clothes to wear before the judge and legal fees she decides to sue him for 200,000 dollars.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/26/1940
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.

item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep918 radar rocket p14 03/06/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/06/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, hack prine 07/05/1954

item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.itunes:summary: Joel McCrea stars as Texas Ranger Jace Pearson in this thirty minute western adventure series. The shows are all reenactments of incidents from Texas Ranger history. item.title: gunsmoke, claustrophobia 06/26/1954

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/26/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: boston blackie, only one way out 11/12/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Two deep sea treasure hunters find their treasure and a double double cross.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/12/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, final payment 09/15/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A little man with big heels tries to run over Marlowe. A giant and a warehouse nearly costs him his life, and a treacherous blonde almost buries him at sea! All this is for a client that could not pay Marlowe a cent, but on whose behalf they were paid in full.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/15/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: burns and allen, beverly hills uplift club 01/17/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: It is morning in the Burns home and George has just come down to breakfast and Gracie has something she would like to ask him. She wants her club, The Beverly Hills Uplift Society to take over their radio show tonight.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/17/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Burns and Allen 1932 - 1950
George Burns and Gracie Allen were performers who successfully moved their stand-up comedy act to radio. There were, in total, over 120 episodes of the situation comedies featuring George and Gracie as a married couple, which they were in real life. The audiences loved Gracie, she was too dainty and ladylike for anyone to even conceive disliking her. As George soon learnt He was quoted as saying -I learned that if I blew a puff of cigar smoke in Gracies direction the audience would hate me- Burns and Allen went on to TV, as did many of the greatest radio stars that had worked in vaudeville.
item.itunes:keywords: burns and allen,otr,old time radio,botar,george burns, gracie allen

item.title: adventures of superman, ep910 radar rocket p6 02/22/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/22/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: boston blackie, uncle frank murdered 07/02/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/02/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep906 radar rocket p2 02/18/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/18/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Blackies friend Shorty, apparently just out of jail, meets an hysterical woman who claims to have seen a ghost. She is the maid of wealthy Mrs. Worthington, the former concert pianist. After the maid dies in a locked room, Mrs. Worthington then sees the ghost.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/19/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, quiet magpie 08/11/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Vincent Calloway is standing trial for the murder of his father, which he did not commit. Marlowe uncovers a complex tale of blackmail and intrigue.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/11/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: escape, red wine 08/11/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: You are with three men in a jungle plantation on the rubber coast of Borneo. You know that one of the men is a desperate criminal who you have come to arrest but you do not know which one. You have to find him before he can save himself by killing you.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/11/1949
item.itunes:summary: Escape was radios leading anthology series of high adventure, airing on CBS from July 7, 1947 to September 25, 1954. Broadcasting a wide range of stories including science fiction, horror, and murder mysteries.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep902 is there another superman p11 02/12/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/12/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, monopoly 05/22/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A businessman from St. Louis named Ivy is planning to take over the freight business in Dodge, with a gunfighter to help him do it.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/22/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 089. in the line of fire 07/10/1937
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 089
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/10/1937
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 109, income tax forms arrive 01/16/1944
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A doghouse for Stinky or Leilas income tax. Not much of a choice.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/16/1944
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, fibbers tune 06/01/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The last appearance of Gale Gordon as Foggy Williams, the weatherman. Fibbers written a tune called Fibbers Tune.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/01/1942
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: X minus one, parade 05/01/1955
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Episode 002. The Martians hire an ad agency to stage a parade which will herald their arrival.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/01/1955
item.itunes:summary: X minus one 1955-1958, From the far horizons of the unknown, come transcribed tales of new dimensions in time and space. These are stories of the future, adventures in which you'll live in a million could be years on a thousand maybe worlds. The National Broadcasting Company in cooperation with Street and Smith, publishers of Astounding Science Fiction, presents X Minus One. X Minus One was a thirty-minute science fiction series totalling 113 episodes and throughout its three years of broadcasting, it always used the same opening, a rocket-launch countdown. The stories were strict science fiction striking out into deep space, exploring thousands of other worlds and galaxies and, the much more exciting, power struggles with aliens. Although the stories were not always human triumphs, sometimes the aliens won. It was broadcast in America from April 1955 to January 1958 on NBC. A revival of Dimension X, X Minus One is widely considered among the finest radio dramas ever produced. The first fifteen episodes were new versions of Dimension X episodes, but the remainder were adaptations of newly published science fiction stories by respected writers such as Frederik Pohl, Theodore Sturgeon, Ray Bradbury, Isaac Asimov and Robert Heinlein, with a few original scripts.

item.description: Fibber has written a song entitled, The War Stamp Stomp.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/24/1942
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: boston blackie, gardenia case 08/06/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Blackie joins the Jerry Williams gang to break up a mob that covers its crimes by intimidating witnesses.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/06/1946
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/12/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep892 is there another superman p1 01/29/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/29/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, mr and mrs amber 04/03/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Neil Amber going through a bad patch and he and his wife can barely afford to eat when he is caught thieving from Jonas. Jonas insisted that Matt Dillon arrest him but Matt sent him on his way and told Jonas to put the cost of the seed he was caught stealing on his Dillons account. Jonas not satisfied then came to Dillon claiming that Mrs. Amber had stolen a calf from him and insisted that Dillon have her arrested.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/03/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: X minus one, perigis wonderful dolls 06/05/1955
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Episode 007. A government officials daughter finds a doll maker in Washington that makes talking dolls.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/05/1955
item.itunes:summary: X minus one 1955-1958, From the far horizons of the unknown, come transcribed tales of new dimensions in time and space. These are stories of the future, adventures in which you'll live in a million could be years on a thousand maybe worlds. The National Broadcasting Company in cooperation with Street and Smith, publishers of Astounding Science Fiction, presents X Minus One. X Minus One was a thirty-minute science fiction series totalling 113 episodes and throughout its three years of broadcasting, it always used the same opening, a rocket-launch countdown. The stories were strict science fiction striking out into deep space, exploring thousands of other worlds and galaxies and, the much more exciting, power struggles with aliens. Although the stories were not always human triumphs, sometimes the aliens won. It was broadcast in America from April 1955 to January 1958 on NBC. A revival of Dimension X, X Minus One is widely considered among the finest radio dramas ever produced. The first fifteen episodes were new versions of Dimension X episodes, but the remainder were adaptations of newly published science fiction stories by respected writers such as Frederik Pohl, Theodore Sturgeon, Ray Bradbury, Isaac Asimov and Robert Heinlein, with a few original scripts.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.title: boston blackie, mary at sea 07/30/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Blackie and Mary were going to Westfield overnight on board a ship to do some business for Charlie Kingston. Mary was deciding whether to have the top bunk or the bottom when Blackie discovered the dead woman in the top bunk.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/30/1945
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:summary:

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/28/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: adventures of superman, ep888 talking cat p11 01/23/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/23/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: sherlock holmes, case of the everblooming roses 05/16/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: sherlock holmes
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/16/1948
item.itunes:summary:
Sherlock Holmes - 1930-1967
The famous Sherlock Holmes detective stories appeared on radio for more than 25 years, with a long list of performers playing the parts of Holmes and Dr Watson. The stories were written by Edith Meiser, a self-confessed Holmes addict. At first she used Arthur Conan Doyles original stories, but, after the series outlived the original material, she created her own new stories. These were so well written that she was warmly praised by Arthur Conan Doyles widow and son.
Throughout the early 1940s on American Radio, Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce performed as Holmes and Watson, respectively, in several series of canonical and original Sherlock Holmes stories. When Rathbone finally departed the role before the 1947 season, Tom Conway played Sherlock Holmes opposite Nigel Bruce for one season. After a change of networks, there were two more pairings: John Stanley as Holmes and Alfred Shirley as Watson in 1947-1948 and John Stanley and Ian Martin in 1948-1949.

When Rathbone finally departed the role before the 1947 season, Tom Conway played Sherlock Holmes opposite Nigel Bruce for one season. After a change of networks, there were two more pairings: John Stanley as Holmes and Alfred Shirley as Watson in 1947-1948 and John Stanley and Ian Martin in 1948-1949.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep884 talking cat p7 01/17/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/17/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, last fling 02/20/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Matt Dillon, the Marshall of Dodge City, is musing with Kitty over the unnecessary violence in the town when a message comes to tell him that the Doc wants him to come and investigate a murder where the suspect is a highly unlikely one.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/20/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep878 talking cat p1 01/09/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/09/1946
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: the whistler, panic 02/04/1946
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: It was a quiet night for San Francisco. The fog drifting in from Leora had been on Kent Buckleys mind all morning. He tried not to think of her but his mind kept going back to her. He stopped and deliberately thought of her of her leaving tonight walking out of his life forever. He went and booked passage on the same ship Leora and Charles Moffit were sailing on that night. He agrees to be sensible to remember that she is married to respectable wealthy Charles Moffit. But it has always been hard for him to be reasonable where Leoras concerned and that night at nine oclock just three hours before sailing time he goes to Leoras hotel to see her but Charles is there and a struggle ensues which ends in a fatality.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/04/1946

item.title: gunsmoke, stage holdup 01/04/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The trip from Hayes City to Dodge was long enough on horseback, but by stage coach it seemed endless. There were only two passengers, besides me, and after the first hour on the road we stopped talking. Just sat there in silence waiting for the ride to be over. Id been up late the past couple of nights, so I braced myself into the corner of the coach and fell asleep. I vaguely remember the stage pulling to a stop and somebody shouting. But I came fully awake when the door was jerked open and a man behind a bandanna stuck a shotgun in my face.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/04/1954
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. item.title: gunsmoke, joke is on us 01/09/1954
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Jake and his men have caught the man that has been stealing their horses. Tillman is Jakes neighbor and they've known each other for a long time. Jake caught Tillman red handed, he was herding the horses away from the farm, even though he claims that he was trying to drive them all home and that one had got away. Tillman said that Jennings saw him herding the horses up, but Jake does not wait to ask him, and hangs him.

item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep872 looking for krytonite p20 12/31/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/31/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: boston blackie, copy of diamond bracelet 10/11/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: boston blackie
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/11/1945
item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

It was bright with youthful charm and the subject was the revolt of youth in the 19teens against the conventional customs of the last century. It is the story of Amory Blain a handsome, spoilt and vain young man a social and intellectual snob whose greatest need was to be admired by others.

item.itunes:summary:
Boston Blackie - 1944-1948
Blackie was a tough, wisecracking private detective working in New York, billed as -enemy to those who make him an enemy, friend to those who have no friend.- His speciality was making fools of the police, a simple task with Inspector Farraday heading the official investigations.
Boston Blackie was a character introduced by Jack Boyle who was featured in a series of mystery films during the silent movie era and in the 1940s. The character appeared in stories in the Redbook and Cosmopolitan magazines. He first appeared in book form in Boston Blackie, published in 1919. The silent film version of Boston Blackie lasted from 1919 until 1927. Over a decade later the screen rights were purchased by Columbia, and a new series ran from 1941 until 1949. In 1944 a Boston Blackie radio show was played by NBC as a replacement. Over 200 episodes were made between 1944 and 1950.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/04/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.

item.title: sherlock holmes, paradol chamber 05/21/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A female scientists wants Dr. Watson and his wife to invest in her invention, a metal which facilitates human teleportation.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/21/1945
item.itunes:summary:
Sherlock Holmes - 1930-1967
The famous Sherlock Holmes detective stories appeared on radio for more than 25 years, with a long list of performers playing the parts of Holmes and Dr Watson. The stories were written by Edith Meiser, a self-confessed Holmes addict. At first she used Arthur Conan Doyles original stories, but, after the series outlived the original material, she created her own new stories. These were so well written that she was warmly praised by Arthur Conan Doyles widow and son.
Throughout the early 1940s on American Radio, Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce performed as Holmes and Watson, respectively, in several series of canonical and original Sherlock Holmes stories. When Rathbone finally departed the role before the 1947 season, Tom Conway played Sherlock Holmes opposite Nigel Bruce for one season. After a change of networks, there were two more pairings: John Stanley as Holmes and Alfred Shirley as Watson in 1947-1948 and John Stanley and Ian Martin in 1948-1949.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/07/1945
item.itunes:summary:
Sherlock Holmes - 1930-1967
The famous Sherlock Holmes detective stories appeared on radio for more than 25 years, with a long list of performers playing the parts of Holmes and Dr Watson. The stories were written by Edith Meiser, a self-confessed Holmes addict. At first she used Arthur Conan Doyles original stories, but, after the series outlived the original material, she created her own new stories. Throughout the early 1940s on American Radio, Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce performed as Holmes and Watson, respectively, in several series of canonical and original Sherlock Holmes stories. After a change of networks, there were two more pairings: John Stanley as Holmes and Alfred Shirley as Watson in 1947-1948 and John Stanley and Ian Martin in 1948-1949.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep868 looking for krytonite p16 12/25/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/25/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

She thought hed lose his chance to be the head of the bank but Charles went out, he saw action with the army air force in Africa and Italy and now as the story opens in the year 1947 Charles is back in the bank but much more quizzical about himself and his job.
