item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/18/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, buffalo hunter 10/24/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gatliff and his men come in to Dodge with their hides but their skinner named Billy got hurt. Doc was unable to save him and he died. Gatliff said he was just a bum who worked for him and he was unwilling to pay for his funeral. Gatliff told Marshal Dillon that Billy had been melting lead for bullets and had burned himself but Matt Dillon doesnt believe that Billys death was an accident.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/24/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: gunsmoke, how to kill a woman 10/31/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: When Jim Bucks Stage is held up and a passenger gun down in cold blood Buck suspects stage station owner Jim Dagget and his partner as they knew he was carrying gold.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/31/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: the whistler, stray dream 11/26/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Chris Cragget was never meant to commit murder, he knew it the minute he did it. Of course, it was too late then. The minute it was over and he looked down at Steve Robinson lying there on the floor, he knew nothing would be the same afterwards, that no matter how perfect it was, no matter how thoroughly he outsmarted the police, the big battle was going to take place inside himself, in the middle of his mind.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/26/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: nbc university theatre, goodbye mr chips 07/09/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Goodbye Mr Chips is a biography of an English schoolmaster who loved his vocation at Brookfield Public School for boys. Mr Chips possessed two gifts, a sympathetic understanding of his pupils and the ability to impart high standards without preaching. Goodbye Mr Chips is told with moving sincerity and gives a background sketch of a public school as it was before and through two world wars. Written by James Hilton.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/09/1949
item.itunes:summary: In 1944, NBC brought the worlds greatest novels to radio, offering high quality adaptations of some of the great works of literature. In 1948, the series was retitled NBC University theatre of the air and production was moved to Hollywood. The first broadcast of the new series aired July 30, 1948. In 1948, the Peabody was awarded to the NBC University Theatre.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 070. lil and dr carstairs find jungle jim 02/27/1937
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 070
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/27/1937
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 077, car wreck with hooker 04/11/1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gildersleeves car is not running well, and Marjories boyfriend is just the fellow to fix the problem.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/11/1943
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: fibber mcgee and molly, cuckoo clock 11/08/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Fibber is determined to fix Teenys cuckoo clock.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/08/1949
item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.
item.itunes:keywords: fibber mcgee and molly,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, vital statistic 03/14/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: This time a carheart knocked me down a flight of stairs, an honest woman was strangled by a green silk sash, and a simpering dandy was shot to death, all becasue of a run of the mill accident 500 miles away.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/14/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.description: bunny berigan, jive
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date, circa 1943
item.itunes:summary: This was a program produced by the Armed Forces Radio Service in Hollywood beginning in 1943, and continuing thru the war years. AFRS was broadcast on a wide range of adhoc stations scattered around areas where the American military was active overseas. None of these broadcasts were intendent to be received stateside.

item.title: escape, S.S. san pedro 08/22/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: You are trapped aboard an ill fated ocean liner, captained by a dying man, whilst a mysterious stranger, haunting you, menacing you, seems intent on sending you to destruction.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/22/1948
item.itunes:summary: Escape was radios leading anthology series of high adventure, airing on CBS from July 7, 1947 to September 25, 1954. Broadcasting a wide range of stories including science fiction, horror, and murder mysteries.

item.title: lights out, rocket from manhattan 09/20/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Prophecy is an easy thing for rarely is the prophet brought to justice. This play brings you a false prophecy. The place of the story is a great rocket speeding away from the moon after the first trip to the moon has finally taken place and a triumphant airship is now returning home to mother earth.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/20/1945
item.itunes:summary: This thirty minute drama was created by Wyllis Cooper and began in 1934 as a regional program featuring tales of suspense and horror. The program was renowned for having the most grisly sound effects ever heard on radio, including the sounds of heads rolling, bones being crushed, people falling from great heights and splattering wetly on the pavement, chokings, heads split by cleavers and the worst of all, the sound of human flesh being eaten

item.title: gunsmoke, how to kill a friend 10/03/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: When two gamblers arrived in Dodge they sent word to Marshall Matt Dillon that they would like to have a word. Ben Quarter and Harry Duggan were business partners who whenever they went to a new town wanted to get to know who was running the place that way they figure there wont be any misunderstanding later on. But they were crooked gamblers and Dillon put them straight that he was a lawman and not open to bribes.

item.title: the whistler, seeing eye 11/12/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: There was only one love in the life of Captain Martin Quist. it wasnt money, he long since made more than enough to retire comfortably. And it wasnt women nor liquor or self indulgence. Captain Quist was part of the sea. It had been his home and his life since the day in 1907 when he signed on as an apprentice seaman. But a love as strong of that of Captain Quists of the sea can be dangerous. It can blind a man to more important things like human decency and justice.

item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: lights out, author and the thing 09/28/1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: It is now 1100 pm and Mr Oboler has to have the next Lights Out play done by tomorrow morning. He insists he will get the story written tonight if he has to talk to the devil himself to do it. He sends his secretary home and then continues to work on a plot himself but for some reason he is feeling very jittery afraid to put his monsters and demons down on paper and this time with every good reason to feel so.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/28/1943
item.itunes:summary: This thirty minute drama was created by Wyllis Cooper and began in 1934 as a regional program featuring tales of suspense and horror. The program was renowned for having the most grisly sound effects ever heard on radio, including the sounds of heads rolling, bones being crushed, people falling from great heights and splattering wetly on the pavement, chokings, heads split by cleavers and the worst of all, the sound of human flesh being eaten

item.title: adventures of superman, ep858 looking for krytonite p6 12/11/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/11/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, prairie happy 09/12/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Marshall Matt Dillon and his deputy Chester have been out of Dodge for a week and arrive back to find out that the whole town is expecting an attack from the Pawnees Indians. Dillon needs to find out who has started this panic in Dodge and why.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/12/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: gunsmoke, there never was a horse 09/19/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Ken Creed was a gunman from Arizona who came to Dodge. In a bar he shot and killed a drunken man in self defence witnessed by Marshall Matt Dillon. He told Dillon he was not proud of killing the man. Dillon knew Creed has a man who killed for a reputation and knew that what would really make Creed proud would be to kill a man as fast on the draw as Dillon. Creed took every opportunity to pick a fight with Dillon.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/19/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. item.title: the whistler, harvest of death 11/05/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: It was not a large farm, but it was not small, either. It kept two strong men busy from sunup to sundown taking care of it. And they did a nice job because the farm prospered. Mort Grant owned the farm and lived in an awkward looking unpainted farmhouse with his wife, Nellie. Jim Hayward was the hired man and lived in a spare bedroom. Actually, he had been there so long he was more like one of the family than a hired hand. And that is what worried Mort.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/05/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/06/1937
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/14/1943
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.itunes:summary: Fibber McGee and Molly was first broadcast in 1935 and ran in a variety of formats until the final broadcast in 1956. Jim and Marian Jordan ,real-life husband and wife Vaudevillians, played Fibber and his wife Molly in this hilarious domestic comedy. The show made good use of running gags. Probably the best remembered is McGees junk-filled closet, which always crashed down on anyone that happened to open the door.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/24/1943
item.itunes:summary: This thirty minute drama was created by Wyllis Cooper and began in 1934 as a regional program featuring tales of suspense and horror. The program was renowned for having the most grisly sound effects ever heard on radio, including the sounds of heads rolling, bones being crushed, people falling from great heights and splattering wetly on the pavement, chokings, heads split by cleavers and the worst of all, the sound of human flesh being eaten

item.title: adventures of superman, ep852 atom man in metropolis p19 12/03/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/03/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

The program was renowned for having the most grisly sound effects ever heard on radio, including the sounds of heads rolling, bones being crushed, people falling from great heights and splattering wetly on the pavement, chokings, heads split by cleavers and the worst of all, the sound of human flesh being eaten

item.title: adventures of superman, ep848 atom man in metropolis p15 11/27/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/27/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, dirt 07/04/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Nat Sibberts was a little wild and had a reputation with the women but was ready to marry Polly and knew that he had to work hard and settle down to be as steady as the next man. Pollys brother Henry does not want his sister to be messed about and tells Nat that he had better be there to marry his sister. Late Marshall Matt Dillon and Chester receive a note at the jail from someone threatening to put a stop to the wedding. It seems somebody wants to kill Nat if he does get married and somebody wants to kill him if he does not.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/04/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: gunsmoke, grass 07/11/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Harry Popes wife had died four months ago and he had moved from Boston out to Dodge and built himself a little house out on the prairie. Now he told Chester that he was scared to death of the Indians in the area but Marshal Matt Dillon advised him that it was most likely not Indians that he could hear hollering and hooting.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 07/11/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. item.title: the whistler, man who died twice 09/24/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A year or more after his second death the public learned the facts in the case of Stash Wilk. They made him famous posthumously as the man who died twice. The story which the public never knew involved, Stash, his brother John, his lawyer Ben Meadow and his girl Eddie Shelby. But the real center of the story was an oil drum containing 400,000 dollars in currency buried near a lonely highway.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/24/1945

item.description: The Mayor of Casterbridge is set in Wessex, England and concerns rain and weather with strong men in conflict and with women fully dependant. It is the story of Michael Henchard a man of character, strong and yet weak, turbulent yet calm, hard and yet sentimental. He lived by his deeds and died by them and was judge for them. Written by Thomas Hardy in 1886.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/01/1949

item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/10/1943
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, covered bridge 01/14/1950

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/14/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The Way of All Flesh 1903 is a semi autobiographical novel by Samuel Butler which attacks Victorian era hypocrisy. Written between 1873 and 1884, it traces four generations of the Pontifex family. It represents a relaxation from the religious outlook from a Calvinistic approach, which is presented as harsh. Butler dared not publish it during his lifetime, but when it was published it was accepted as part of the general revolution against Victorianism.

The program was renowned for having the most grisly sound effects ever heard on radio, including the sounds of heads rolling, bones being crushed, people falling from great heights and splattering wetly on the pavement, chokings, heads split by cleavers and the worst of all, the sound of human flesh being eaten

item.title: adventures of superman, ep842 atom man in metropolis p9 11/19/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/19/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, fall semester 05/30/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Lee Dorgan came stumbling in to the jail house declaring that he was drunk and wanted his gun taking off him and wanted to be locked up to prevent himself from killing a man named Jim Solder. Lee knew he was drunk enough to know he wanted to kill him but was sober enough to know that he was too drunk to kill. Matt Dillon wanted to find out what the beef was between the two men.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/30/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: gunsmoke, print asper 05/23/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: John Asper had last killed a man in the Spring of 1869 and had decided then he would never kill another man but now he had changed his mind. A few weeks back he had been to see a clever lawyer named Rabb and signed some transfer papers saying that his boys owned his ranch now and would not have to wait until he died but Rabb knowing that Asper could not read cheated him out of his ranch. Asper felt that he had no alternative but to kill Rabb.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/23/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/09/1945
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: gunsmoke, gonif 04/11/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Marshall Matt Dillon was surprised to see Buffalo Mason and Frank Bissell after he had told them not to show their faces in town again.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/11/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: gunsmoke, bums rush 04/18/1953
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gorse and Orlo were two friends who were broke and needed some money. When the storekeeper refused to hand over the money and drew a gun on them they killed him. Matt Dillon arrested them and they were just happy to be getting fed. Meantime George Blaine was appealing for their release but he had his own reason for doing so.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/18/1953
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: the whistler, death pays a visit 06/11/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The Crowleys are a typical young married couple the kind you probably have living on your block. A little more prosperous than most perhaps drive a better car have nicer clothes you know. Funny too because Jake Crowley only earns 47.50 dollars a week as assistant manager of a branch of Sellers national bank and the neighbors may be surprised to learn that the Crowleys have only 321.17 dollars in their in their joint bank account.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/11/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: nbc university theatre, marble fawn 03/20/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: NBC University Theater brings you Nathaniel Hawthornes brilliant novel The Marble Faun a work highly invested with symbolism and rich with poetic effect.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/20/1949
item.itunes:summary: In 1944, NBC brought the worlds greatest novels to radio, offering high quality adaptations of some of the great works of literature. In 1948, the series was retitled NBC University theatre of the air and production was moved to Hollywood. The first broadcast of the new series aired July 30, 1948. In 1948, the Peabody was awarded to the NBC University Theatre.

item.title: jungle jim, episode 057. on flanders fields 11/28/1936
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 057
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/28/1936
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 057, thanksgiving B ration book 11/22/1942
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Gildersleeve tries to get a B ration book.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/22/1942
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: adventures of philip marlowe, fine italian hand 11/05/1949
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A broken body in a quiet house, gunplay on a merry go round at midnight and a boy and a girl in love running away all because of one mans fine Italian Hand.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/05/1949
item.itunes:summary: The Adventures of Philip Marlowe was a radio detective drama that aired from 1947 through 1951, first heard on NBC in the summer of 1947 starring Van Heflin. It appeared on CBS in the fall of 1948 starring Gerald Mohr. Philip Marlowe is a fictional character created by Raymond Chandler in a series of novels. The wisecracking, hard drinking, quietly contemplative, tough private eye, is from the genre of hardboiled crime fiction that originated in the 1920s.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of philip marlowe,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: GI Jive, AFRS 855, circa 1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: stan kenton, eager beaver
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date, circa 1943
item.itunes:summary: This was a program produced by the Armed Forces Radio Service in Hollywood beginning in 1943, and continuing thru the war years. AFRS was broadcast on a wide range of adhoc stations scattered around areas where the American military was active overseas. None of these broadcasts were intendent to be received stateside.

item.title: escape, brute 04/11/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: You are in mid ocean aboard a jinx ship, already nine men have died and you know that some malignant force is aimed at you from which you can not escape. The Brute was written Joseph Conrad and is set in the North Atlantic in the year 1900 about a sailing ship whose very name struck dread in to a sailors heart.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/11/1948
item.itunes:summary: Escape was radios leading anthology series of high adventure, airing on CBS from July 7, 1947 to September 25, 1954. Broadcasting a wide range of stories including science fiction, horror, and murder mysteries.

item.title: lights out, spider 05/18/1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Two men are in the jungle of the upper Amazon collecting butterflies when one of them sees a spider as big as a dog and decides that if they can trap the spider he will be able to take it back to the USA and make his fortune showing it in a circus.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/18/1943
item.itunes:summary: This thirty minute drama was created by Wyllis Cooper and began in 1934 as a regional program featuring tales of suspense and horror. The program was renowned for having the most grisly sound effects ever heard on radio, including the sounds of heads rolling, bones being crushed, people falling from great heights and splattering wetly on the pavement, chokings, heads split by cleavers and the worst of all, the sound of human flesh being eaten

item.title: the whistler, murder is blind 06/04/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Most people are blind. Yes they are blind to the shortcomings of someone close to them someone sometimes to their own. That was the way with the three women who lived in the old Hopkins house on the hill, three very different women but all of them blind to the characters of the others. There was Lola Hopkins mistress of the house, warm sincere Lola happy in her coming marriage to Gregory. There was Patsy Hopkins Lolas cousin whose only happiness is in herself her youth, her loveliness and old Fraulein the German housekeeper who has been Patsys governess and who had found happiness with serving her with years of devotion. None of them really knew the others; all of them were a little blind that is until it happened.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/04/1945
item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: the whistler, escape to danger 05/28/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: To Frederick Pontiac an American citizen caught in Germany during the war, death came slowly and painfully by starvation and torture in a cellar of a Nazi prison camp. But death was not the end for Frederick Pontiac it was the beginning of a new and bizarre chapter for he died only a few days too early and his body was hardly cold before his captors saw the handwriting on the wall put there by allied shells. Yes the Nazis hours were numbered they all knew it and that was a plan was hatched by commander Ernst Von Muller commandant of the prison a man high on the list of war criminals.

During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.

On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.

item.title: war on japan, 12/08/1941
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: FDR declares war on japan
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/08/1941
item.itunes:summary: Yesterday, Dec. 7, 1941 - a date which will live in infamy - the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan. The United States was at peace with that nation and, at the solicitation of Japan, was still in conversation with the government and its emperor looking toward the maintenance of peace in the Pacific. Indeed, one hour after Japanese air squadrons had commenced bombing in Oahu, the Japanese ambassador to the United States and his colleagues delivered to the Secretary of State a formal reply to a recent American message. While this reply stated that it seemed useless to continue the existing diplomatic negotiations, it contained no threat or hint of war or armed attack. It will be recorded that the distance of Hawaii from Japan makes it obvious that the attack was deliberately planned many days or even weeks ago. During the intervening time, the Japanese government has deliberately sought to deceive the United States by false statements and expressions of hope for continued peace. The attack yesterday on the Hawaiian islands has caused severe damage to American naval and military forces. Very many American lives have been lost. In addition, American ships have been reported torpedoed on the high seas between San Francisco and Honolulu. Yesterday, the Japanese government also launched an attack against Malaya. Last night, Japanese forces attacked Hong Kong. Last night, Japanese forces attacked Guam. Last night, Japanese forces attacked the Philippine Islands. Last night, the Japanese attacked Wake Island. This morning, the Japanese attacked Midway Island. Japan has, therefore, undertaken a surprise offensive extending throughout the Pacific area. The facts of yesterday speak for themselves. The people of the United States have already formed their opinions and well understand the implications to the very life and safety of our nation. As commander in chief of the Army and Navy, I have directed that all measures be taken for our defense. Always will we remember the character of the onslaught against us. No matter how long it may take us to overcome this premeditated invasion, the American people in their righteous might will win through to absolute victory. I believe I interpret the will of the Congress and of the people when I assert that we will not only defend ourselves to the uttermost, but will make very certain that this form of treachery shall never endanger us again.Hostilities exist. There is no blinking at the fact that our people, our territory and our interests are in grave danger.With confidence in our armed forces - with the unbounding determination of our people - we will gain the inevitable triumph - so help us God. I ask that the Congress declare that since the unprovoked and dastardly attack by Japan on Sunday, Dec. 7, a state of war has existed between the United States and the Japanese empire.
item.itunes:keywords: war on japan,FDR,pearl harbor,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: World War II news, 04/27/1945
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: World War II news
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/27/1945
item.itunes:summary:
World War II was a global military conflict that took place between 1939 and 1945. It was the largest and deadliest war in history.
The war began in 1939 between Germany and the Allies. The Allies were initially made up of Poland, the British Commonwealth, France, and others. Germany, Italy, and Japan in 1940 signed a mutual defense agreement, the Tripartite Pact, and were known as the Axis Powers. In June 1941, Germany invaded the Soviet Union, forcing the Soviets into the Allied camp. In December 1941, Japan attacked the United States bringing it too into the war on the Allied side. China, which had been at war with Japan since the mid-1930s, also joined the Allies, as eventually did most of the rest of the world.
item.itunes:keywords: world war II news,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: jack benny program, back from new york 04/04/1937
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: we are the botar
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/04/1937
item.itunes:summary:
Jack Benny Program, 1932 - 1955
Benny Kubelsky was born in Chicago, Illinois, on February 14, 1894. He grew up in Waukegan, Illinois, and would later become Jack Benny.
As a young boy, he was encouraged by his Jewish immigrant parents from Poland to achieve respectability as a violinist. He showed enough talent to hit the vaudeville stage, where he played popular songs, adopted a suave-but-fragile personality, and told self-deprecating jokes.
When columnist/broadcaster Ed Sullivan invited Benny on his program on March 19, 1932, the persona was effective. Benny got his own twice-weekly show later that year on CBS. Benny became an enormously successful national figure with The Jack Benny Program, a weekly radio show which ran from 1932 to 1948 on NBC and he returned to CBS from 1948 to May 22, 1955.
